income.heading: Monthly take-home income
income.description: Use your after-tax income (net pay) for the month—what actually lands in your checking account.

tip.text: If your pay varies, use a 3–6 month average so your budget doesn’t swing wildly month to month.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: If you get paid biweekly, multiply your average paycheck by 26 and divide by 12 to estimate a monthly amount.

categories.heading: Housing (incl. utilities)
categories.description: Rent or mortgage, property taxes, HOA dues, basic home maintenance, and household utilities like electricity, water, gas, trash, and internet.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Review major housing-related bills once per year (insurance, utilities, subscriptions) to prevent slow budget creep.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: Use a monthly subscription review to catch auto-renewals and re-negotiate providers when possible.

categories.heading: Food
categories.description: Groceries, household staples, work/school lunches, restaurants, takeout, coffee, snacks, and delivery fees.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Plan a few repeatable meals each week and reuse ingredients to reduce food waste and spending.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: Track “convenience spending” (delivery, impulse snacks) separately so it’s visible and easier to reduce.

categories.heading: Transportation
categories.description: Car payments, fuel, insurance, maintenance, parking, tolls, public transit, rideshares, and other commuting costs.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Average irregular costs (repairs, registration, tires) into a monthly estimate so they don’t surprise you later.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: Compare insurance annually and revisit deductibles—small changes can produce meaningful savings.

categories.heading: Healthcare
categories.description: Health insurance premiums, copays, prescriptions, dental/vision, therapy, and out-of-pocket medical expenses.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Build a small monthly healthcare buffer even if you’re healthy—medical spending often arrives in bursts.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: If you have access to tax-advantaged accounts (HSA/FSA), plan contributions around expected annual expenses.

categories.heading: Lifestyle / Discretionary
categories.description: Entertainment, clothing, personal care, hobbies, subscriptions, gifts, vacations, and other non-essential spending.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Give yourself a realistic “fun money” amount—over-restriction often backfires and leads to overspending later.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: Create a short “pause list” for discretionary buys—wait 24–72 hours before purchasing to reduce impulse spending.

categories.heading: Savings / Goals
categories.description: Emergency fund, retirement contributions, debt payoff beyond minimums, sinking funds, and progress toward financial goals.

tip.text: Tip placeholder: Start with small, automatic transfers—consistency matters more than size at the beginning.

superTip.heading: Super+ Tip
superTip.text: Super+ tip placeholder: Use goal-based buckets (emergency, car repair, vacation) so your “remaining” money has a job.
